subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
author: April Abercrombie
full_text:
------=_NextPart_000_00F2_01C9D17E.9A23ED20
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

I have not personally experienced the loss myself. Jon from this list is th=
e one who originally told me about it. I have also heard of it happening to=
 a few other people. After my conversation with Jon, I talked to a computer=
 professional, and he told me that you can experience loss in attached file=
s.

I don't know if you would be able to tell loss of quality in an audio f=
ile with a bit-level comparison. Just because the data has been replaced, d=
oesn't have to mean it is perfect.

Did you listen to the before and after =
results?

Jon-Please relay your experience with the loss of quality on emai=
led files.


  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Rj 
  To: EVP-ITC@yaho=
ogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 2:38 PM
  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] =
File uploading rules





        I can't vouch for your computer or server=
s, but I just did some tests, and sent a 2.1MB wav file from MSN to Yahoo a=
nd back, once allowing compression, and once turning it off.   I was able t=
o verify that one was compressed and one was not, by checking the sizes whe=
n they arrived at Yahoo. Once they came back to MSN, I then did a bit-level=
 comparison of the original, and the ones sent around email.  They were all=
 identical, which indicates lossless compression.

        If you have a fi=
le you'd like me to test for you, let me know.  But I wouldn't take someone=
's word for how your server's work, without testing them yourself.



     =
   --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombieghostresearch.c=
om> wrote:


          From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombieghostresea=
rch.com>
          Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
          To=
: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
          Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 12:50 PM


=

          For executables, you may be right. However, for wav files, the c=
ompression during email is not loss less. 

          I used to think as yo=
u do, in that the emailed attachment of a wav file would not loose anything=
. After a lengthy discourse with another member here, I learned that I was =
wrong. The reason why I did not realize it in the first place is that when =
I would email a wav file, I would intentionally keep it in very small segme=
nts, to keep file size down. This was just for ease of transfer. But becaus=
e of this, I had not experienced any noticeable loss.

          Now it may=
 be in some cases, depending on the servers or what have you that the file =
goes through, that the loss may be less or more. But once the attachment is=
 downloaded, the quality has been found to be less then the original wav.

=
          Again though you can only really tell when the wav file is large.=


          ----- Original Message ----- 
            From: Rj 
           =
 To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
            Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 1:36 =
PM
            Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules


              =
    The kind of compression that occurs during an email attachment is "loss=
less": it compress the file cleverly without losing information.  For examp=
le, if I had a program in some .exe files, and I sent it over email, it cou=
ld compress it.  But if it lost even one bit, the resulting exe file would =
not execute again after it was uncompressed on the other side.

           =
       This kind of compression does things like looking for common pattern=
s in the file, and replacing them with a token.  A rough example would be i=
f it found "Howdy Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it could replace all the oc=
curances with say $HN1.  And also write a little dictionary in there somepl=
ace that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neighbor".

                  When the file get=
s to its destination it can be uncompressed, and all occurences of $HN1 are=
 replaced with "Howdy Neighbor".  So it was compressed (instead of 14 chara=
cters each, it only needed 4, plus the dictionary), but lost no data.

    =
              Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. are not lossless.  Depending=
 on the level of compression, some level of data is lost, and so cannot be =
recovered or reconstructed later.

                  Rick



              =
    --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch=
. com> wrote:


                    From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrom=
biegh ostresearch. com>
                    Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File upl=
oading rules
                    To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
             =
       Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 10:26 AM



                    Another =
thing:

                    I recently found this out. When you email a fil=
e, if it is not saved as a compressed format, the email filtering process w=
ill actually compress the file automatically.

                    So even =
if you have attached a wav. file, it will loose resolution over the email p=
rocess. It will not sound exactly the same as the original wav. file. How m=
uch it differs depends on the size of the file you are attaching. If it is =
a very large file, it will sound much different.

                    The o=
nly exception to this is if the wav. file is small enough that the filterin=
g process will ignore it. It has to be pretty small though, like under 1 MB=
 (I am not exactly sure of the threshold).

                    The best wa=
y to share files over the internet if you want them as close to the origina=
l as possible is to upload them directly to a website.

                   =
   ----- Original Message ----- 
                      From: Rj 
          =
            To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                      Sent: Sunda=
y, May 10, 2009 10:54 AM
                      Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File =
uploading rules



                            Pixelization doesn't clean-u=
p the data: it replaces it.  Imagine taking a picture of a field of flowers=
, and beginning to add levels or pixelization to the picture.  Soon, you wo=
uld not be able to tell there were flowers there at all.  You would see a l=
ot of colored blocks.

                            Or in the other directio=
n, imagine you are looking at a competely randomize bunch of pixes on your =
screen: a complete screen of truely random static snow.  Pixelizing this, a=
fter a while, you would again start to see colored blocks.

               =
             What's happening is that it is processing an area of the image=
, taking (for instance) the average value of that entire area, and replacin=
g all the blocks in that area with the average.  In video processing, this =
would result in a field of multi-colored flowers being replaced by, for ins=
tance, a big greyish-bluish block, with no resemblance to flowers.  In the =
noise example, it maybe replace all the random pixels with another big grey=
ish-bluish block.  If you did not know beforehand what the original picture=
 was, you couldn't tell whether your pixelized image was really a field of =
flowers, a chevy, the sky with clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.

      =
                      It works the same with the sound files.  Taking somet=
hing as complex as speech, and replacing frequencies with their averages, l=
oses the speech the farther you go, until you head strange fluctuating squa=
re waves.  Doing the same to random static will eventually produce the same=
 thing.  And random fluctuating square waves can sound a bit like speech - =
or at least, you could have fun sharing with each other what you thing they=
 'sound like'.





                            --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty =
Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:


                              From: =
Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com>
                              Subject: =
Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                              To: EVP-IT=
C@yahoogroups .com
                              Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009=
, 9:29 AM


                                I always save the whole file in=
 wav format then do my clips as mp3. Then I have the original for analysis.=
 

                                As far as pixelization of non sounds/whi=
te noise whos to say that isnt being manipulated by them as well LOL. Water=
 is a form of white noise. I seem to remember some experiments done with bl=
ank tapes/film, no recording done yet there were voices/images there. I fin=
d it all interesting.

                                Just a thought. Ok o=
ff to work now!
                                Misty

                    =
            --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com> wrote:


        =
                        From: Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com>
                    =
            Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                   =
             To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                D=
ate: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 11:47 AM


                                Be a =
bit careful of formats like mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the=
 sounds though.   While some formats (like wav) can store the audio very cl=
ose to the way it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress the file, and in =
so doing lose some of the sonic details.  This may not be a big deal in mus=
ic, where the audio is fairly clear to begin with.  But with sound sources =
with a lot of noise (like evps), this can not only obscure any real sounds,=
 but pixelize non-sounds (like white noise) and make them start to sound li=
ke speech.

                                So mp3 might be good for sharin=
g the data, once you've already formed an opinion based on an analysis of t=
he wav file.  But mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis.  It can lead to=
 many false positives and misinterpretations.

                            =
    --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:


     =
                           From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com>
      =
                          Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
     =
                           To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                   =
             Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 8:26 AM


                        =
        Thanks =3D)

                                 You will get the hang=
 of it. Kristen is right thats how you save it. For most softwares its unde=
r save as or export as. If you still have trouble use one of the links I po=
sted to help ya out.

                                Misty

              =

                                Please do not upload wav format files her=

                       =
         Misty

one"><B>Subject:</B>

er=3D0 cellSpacing=3D0 cellPadding=3D0>
                        <TBODY>
   =
                     <TR>
                          <TD vAlign=3Dtop><BR>Pi=
xelization doesn't clean-up the 
                            data: it repla=
ces it.  Imagine taking a picture 
                            of a fi=
eld of flowers, and beginning to add levels 
                            or=
 pixelization to the picture.  Soon, you 
                            =
would not be able to tell there were flowers there 
                       =
     at all.  You would see a lot of colored 
                        =
    blocks.<BR><BR>Or in the other direction, imagine 
                    =
        you are looking at a competely randomize bunch of 
                =
            pixes on your screen: a complete screen of truely 
            =
                random static snow.  Pixelizing this, after a 
       =
                     while, you would again start to see colored 
         =
                   blocks.<BR><BR>What's happening is that it is 
         =
                   processing an area of the image, taking (for 
          =
                  instance) the average value of that entire area, and 
   =
                         replacing all the blocks in that area with the 
  =
                          average.  In video processing, this would 
 =
                           result in a field of multi-colored flowers being=
 
                            replaced by, for instance, a big greyish-blui=
sh 
                            block, with no resemblance to flowers.&nbsp=
; In the 
                            noise example, it maybe replace all t=
he random 
                            pixels with another big greyish-blui=
sh block.  
                            If you did not know beforehand=
 what the original 
                            picture was, you couldn't t=
ell whether your 
                            pixelized image was really a =
field of flowers, a 
                            chevy, the sky with clouds=
, or a random bunch of 
                            pixels.<BR><BR>It works=
 the same with the sound 
                            files.  Taking s=
omething as complex as speech, 
                            and replacing f=
requencies with their averages, loses 
                            the spee=
ch the farther you go, until you head 
                            strange =
fluctuating square waves.  Doing the 
                            same=
 to random static will eventually produce the 
                            =
same thing.  And random fluctuating square 
                          =
  waves can sound a bit like speech - or at least, you 
                   =
         could have fun sharing with each other what you 
                 =
           thing they 'sound like'.<BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR>--- 
           =
                 On <B>Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <I><bulletbabea@ 
      =
                      yahoo.com></I></B> wrote:<BR>

AM<BR><BR>

941>

=3D0 cellPadding=3D0>

              =
                  style=3D"FONT-FAMILY: inherit; font-size-adjust: inherit"=
 
                                vAlign=3Dtop>
                           =
     <DIV>I always save the whole file in wav format 
                     =
           then do my clips as mp3. Then I have the 
                      =
          original for analysis. </DIV>
                                <DI=
V> </DIV>
                                <DIV>As far as pixelization =
of non sounds/white 
                                noise whos to say that=
 isnt being manipulated by 
                                them as well LO=
L. Water is a form of white 
                                noise. I seem =
to remember some experiments done 
                                with bla=
nk tapes/film, no recording done 
                                yet =
there were voices/images there. I find it 
                                =
all interesting.</DIV>
                                <DIV> </DIV>
  =
                              <DIV>Just a thought. Ok off to work now!</DIV=
>

ellSpacing=3D0 cellPadding=3D0>

   =
                             <TR>
                                <TD vAlig=
n=3Dtop>Be a bit careful of formats like 
                                m=
p3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the 
                           =
     sounds though.   While some formats 
                       =
         (like wav) can store the audio very close to the 
                =
                way it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress 
           =
                     the file, and in so doing lose some of the sonic 
    =
                            details.  This may not be a big deal in 
 =
                               music, where the audio is fairly clear to be=
gin 
                                with.  But with sound sources wit=
h a lot of 
                                noise (like evps), this can not=
 only obscure any 
                                real sounds, but pixeliz=
e non-sounds (like white 
                                noise) and make t=
hem start to sound like 
                                speech.<BR><BR>So =
mp3 might be good for sharing 
                                the data, on=
ce you've already formed an opinion 
                                based =
on an analysis of the wav file.  But 
                                =
mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis.  
                          =
      It can lead to many false positives and 
                            =
    misinterpretations.<BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
                            =
    5/10/09, Misty Dawn <I><bulletbabea@ 
                              =
  yahoo.com></I></B> wrote:<BR>
